answer_latex:
where the values of $q(10) =2$ are read from the given degree 2 Taylor
polynomial expansion and similarly for $q'(10)$.
hints_html:
Recall that the formula for the price-elasticity of demand is

\(\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{p\cdot q'(p)}{q(p)}\).

The problem requests that we fine \(\epsilon(10)\) which is given by

\(\displaystyle \epsilon(10) = \frac{10\cdot q'(10)}{q(10)}\)

so we need to find the values \(q(10)\) and \(q'(10)\). How can we do this with the given information?

Recall that the quadratic approximation is just the second degree Taylor polynomial given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle T_{2}(p) = q(10) + q'(10)(p - 10) + \frac{1}{2}q''(10)(p-10)^{2}.\end{aligned}\]

Compare this with the given to find the unknown values as given in the previous hint.

hints_raw:
Recall that the formula for the price-elasticity of demand is

<math> \displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{p\cdot q'(p)}{q(p)}</math>.
The problem requests that we fine <math> \epsilon(10) </math> which is given by

<math> \displaystyle \epsilon(10) = \frac{10\cdot q'(10)}{q(10)}</math>

so we need to find the values <math> q(10) </math> and <math> q'(10) </math>. How can we do this with the given information?
Recall that the quadratic approximation is just the second degree Taylor polynomial given by

:<math>
\displaystyle T_{2}(p) = q(10) + q'(10)(p - 10) + \frac{1}{2}q''(10)(p-10)^{2}.
</math>

Compare this with the given to find the unknown values as given in the previous hint.
question: 1 (k)
sols_html:
Using the hints, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \epsilon(p) &= \frac{p \cdot q'(p)}{q(p)} \\ \epsilon(10) &= \frac{10 \cdot q'(10)}{q(10)} = \frac{10 (-4))}{2} = -20\end{aligned}\]

where the values of \(q(10) =2\) are read from the given degree 2 Taylor polynomial expansion and similarly for \(q'(10)\).
sols_latex:

\begin{align*}
\epsilon(p) &= \frac{p \cdot q'(p)}{q(p)} \\
\epsilon(10) &= \frac{10 \cdot q'(10)}{q(10)} = \frac{10 (-4))}{2} = -20
\end{align*}

where the values of $q(10) =2$ are read from the given degree 2 Taylor
polynomial expansion and similarly for $q'(10)$.

<math>
\begin{align}
\epsilon(p) &= \frac{p \cdot q'(p)}{q(p)} \\
\epsilon(10) &= \frac{10 \cdot q'(10)}{q(10)} = \frac{10 (-4))}{2} = -20
\end{align}
</math>

where the values of <math> q(10) =2 </math> are read from the given degree 2 Taylor polynomial expansion and similarly for <math> q'(10) </math>.
statement_html:
The quadratic approximation of a demand function q(p) at p=10 is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}T_2(p)=2-4(p-10)+3(p-10)^2.\end{aligned}\]

Calculuate \(\epsilon(10)\) where \(\epsilon(p)\) is the price-elasticity of demand.
statement_raw:
The quadratic approximation of a demand function q(p) at p=10 is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}T_2(p)=2-4(p-10)+3(p-10)^2.
</math>

Calculuate <math>\epsilon(10)</math> where <math>\epsilon(p)</math> is the price-elasticity of demand.
